entry.title: Codeforces Round #634 (Div. 3)
entry.content:
Codeforces Round #634 (Div. 3)

A

A. Candies and Two Sisters(é¢˜ç›®é“¾æ¥)
A. Candies and Two Sisters
time limit per test1 second
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
There are two sisters Alice and Betty. You have ğ‘› candies. You want to distribute these ğ‘› candies between two sisters in such a way that:

Alice will get ğ‘ (ğ‘>0) candies;
Betty will get ğ‘ (ğ‘>0) candies;
each sister will get some integer number of candies;
Alice will get a greater amount of candies than Betty (i.e. ğ‘>ğ‘);
all the candies will be given to one of two sisters (i.e. ğ‘+ğ‘=ğ‘›).
Your task is to calculate the number of ways to distribute exactly ğ‘› candies between sisters in a way described above. Candies are indistinguishable.

Formally, find the number of ways to represent ğ‘› as the sum of ğ‘›=ğ‘+ğ‘, where ğ‘ and ğ‘ are positive integers and ğ‘>ğ‘.

You have to answer ğ‘¡ independent test cases.

Input
The first line of the input contains one integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤104) â€” the number of test cases. Then ğ‘¡ test cases follow.

The only line of a test case contains one integer ğ‘› (1â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤2â‹…109) â€” the number of candies you have.

Output
For each test case, print the answer â€” the number of ways to distribute exactly ğ‘› candies between two sisters in a way described in the problem statement. If there is no way to satisfy all the conditions, print 0.

Example
inputCopy
6
7
1
2
3
2000000000
763243547
outputCopy
3
0
0
1
999999999
381621773
Note
For the test case of the example, the 3 possible ways to distribute candies are:

ğ‘=6, ğ‘=1;
ğ‘=5, ğ‘=2;
ğ‘=4, ğ‘=3.

B

B. Construct the String(é¢˜ç›®é“¾æ¥)
B. Construct the String
time limit per test2 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
You are given three positive integers ğ‘›, ğ‘ and ğ‘. You have to construct a string ğ‘  of length ğ‘› consisting of lowercase Latin letters such that each substring of length ğ‘ has exactly ğ‘ distinct letters. It is guaranteed that the answer exists.

You have to answer ğ‘¡ independent test cases.

Recall that the substring ğ‘ [ğ‘™â€¦ğ‘Ÿ] is the string ğ‘ ğ‘™,ğ‘ ğ‘™+1,â€¦,ğ‘ ğ‘Ÿ and its length is ğ‘Ÿâˆ’ğ‘™+1. In this problem you are only interested in substrings of length ğ‘.

Input
The first line of the input contains one integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤2000) â€” the number of test cases. Then ğ‘¡ test cases follow.

The only line of a test case contains three space-separated integers ğ‘›, ğ‘ and ğ‘ (1â‰¤ğ‘â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤2000,1â‰¤ğ‘â‰¤min(26,ğ‘)), where ğ‘› is the length of the required string, ğ‘ is the length of a substring and ğ‘ is the required number of distinct letters in each substring of length ğ‘.

It is guaranteed that the sum of ğ‘› over all test cases does not exceed 2000 (âˆ‘ğ‘›â‰¤2000).

Output
For each test case, print the answer â€” such a string ğ‘  of length ğ‘› consisting of lowercase Latin letters that each substring of length ğ‘ has exactly ğ‘ distinct letters. If there are multiple valid answers, print any of them. It is guaranteed that the answer exists.

Example
inputCopy
4
7 5 3
6 1 1
6 6 1
5 2 2
outputCopy
tleelte
qwerty
vvvvvv
abcde
Note
In the first test case of the example, consider all the substrings of length 5:

â€œtleelâ€: it contains 3 distinct (unique) letters,
â€œleeltâ€: it contains 3 distinct (unique) letters,
â€œeelteâ€: it contains 3 distinct (unique) letters.

C

C. Two Teams Composing(é¢˜ç›®é“¾æ¥)
C. Two Teams Composing
time limit per test2 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
You have ğ‘› students under your control and you have to compose exactly two teams consisting of some subset of your students. Each student had his own skill, the ğ‘–-th student skill is denoted by an integer ğ‘ğ‘– (different students can have the same skills).

So, about the teams. Firstly, these two teams should have the same size. Two more constraints:

The first team should consist of students with distinct skills (i.e. all skills in the first team are unique).
The second team should consist of students with the same skills (i.e. all skills in the second team are equal).
Note that it is permissible that some student of the first team has the same skill as a student of the second team.

Consider some examples (skills are given):

[1,2,3], [4,4] is not a good pair of teams because sizes should be the same;
[1,1,2], [3,3,3] is not a good pair of teams because the first team should not contain students with the same skills;
[1,2,3], [3,4,4] is not a good pair of teams because the second team should contain students with the same skills;
[1,2,3], [3,3,3] is a good pair of teams;
[5], [6] is a good pair of teams.
Your task is to find the maximum possible size ğ‘¥ for which it is possible to compose a valid pair of teams, where each team size is ğ‘¥ (skills in the first team needed to be unique, skills in the second team should be the same between them). A student cannot be part of more than one team.

You have to answer ğ‘¡ independent test cases.

Input
The first line of the input contains one integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤104) â€” the number of test cases. Then ğ‘¡ test cases follow.

The first line of the test case contains one integer ğ‘› (1â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤2â‹…105) â€” the number of students. The second line of the test case contains ğ‘› integers ğ‘1,ğ‘2,â€¦,ğ‘ğ‘› (1â‰¤ğ‘ğ‘–â‰¤ğ‘›), where ğ‘ğ‘– is the skill of the ğ‘–-th student. Different students can have the same skills.

It is guaranteed that the sum of ğ‘› over all test cases does not exceed 2â‹…105 (âˆ‘ğ‘›â‰¤2â‹…105).

Output
For each test case, print the answer â€” the maximum possible size ğ‘¥ for which it is possible to compose a valid pair of teams, where each team size is ğ‘¥.

Example
inputCopy
4
7
4 2 4 1 4 3 4
5
2 1 5 4 3
1
1
4
1 1 1 3
outputCopy
3
1
0
2
Note
In the first test case of the example, it is possible to construct two teams of size 3: the first team is [1,2,4] and the second team is [4,4,4]. Note, that there are some other ways to construct two valid teams of size 3.

D

D. Anti-Sudoku(é¢˜ç›®é“¾æ¥)
D. Anti-Sudoku
time limit per test2 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
You are given a correct solution of the sudoku puzzle. If you donâ€™t know what is the sudoku, you can read about it here.

The picture showing the correct sudoku solution:

Blocks are bordered with bold black color.

Your task is to change at most 9 elements of this field (i.e. choose some 1â‰¤ğ‘–,ğ‘—â‰¤9 and change the number at the position (ğ‘–,ğ‘—) to any other number in range [1;9]) to make it anti-sudoku. The anti-sudoku is the 9Ã—9 field, in which:

Any number in this field is in range [1;9];
each row contains at least two equal elements;
each column contains at least two equal elements;
each 3Ã—3 block (you can read what is the block in the link above) contains at least two equal elements.
It is guaranteed that the answer exists.

You have to answer ğ‘¡ independent test cases.

Input
The first line of the input contains one integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤104) â€” the number of test cases. Then ğ‘¡ test cases follow.

Each test case consists of 9 lines, each line consists of 9 characters from 1 to 9 without any whitespaces â€” the correct solution of the sudoku puzzle.

Output
For each test case, print the answer â€” the initial field with at most 9 changed elements so that the obtained field is anti-sudoku. If there are several solutions, you can print any. It is guaranteed that the answer exists.

E1. Three Blocks Palindrome
E1. Three Blocks Palindrome (easy version)
time limit per test3 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
The only difference between easy and hard versions is constraints.

You are given a sequence ğ‘ consisting of ğ‘› positive integers.

Letâ€™s define a three blocks palindrome as the sequence, consisting of at most two distinct elements (let these elements are ğ‘ and ğ‘, ğ‘ can be equal ğ‘) and is as follows: [ğ‘,ğ‘,â€¦,ğ‘î„½î„¾î…î…‹î…‹ğ‘¥,ğ‘,ğ‘,â€¦,ğ‘î„½î„¾î…î…‹î…‹ğ‘¦,ğ‘,ğ‘,â€¦,ğ‘î„½î„¾î…î…‹î…‹ğ‘¥]. There ğ‘¥,ğ‘¦ are integers greater than or equal to 0. For example, sequences [], [2], [1,1], [1,2,1], [1,2,2,1] and [1,1,2,1,1] are three block palindromes but [1,2,3,2,1], [1,2,1,2,1] and [1,2] are not.

Your task is to choose the maximum by length subsequence of ğ‘ that is a three blocks palindrome.

You have to answer ğ‘¡ independent test cases.

Recall that the sequence ğ‘¡ is a a subsequence of the sequence ğ‘  if ğ‘¡ can be derived from ğ‘  by removing zero or more elements without changing the order of the remaining elements. For example, if ğ‘ =[1,2,1,3,1,2,1], then possible subsequences are: [1,1,1,1], [3] and [1,2,1,3,1,2,1], but not [3,2,3] and [1,1,1,1,2].

Input
The first line of the input contains one integer ğ‘¡ (1â‰¤ğ‘¡â‰¤2000) â€” the number of test cases. Then ğ‘¡ test cases follow.

The first line of the test case contains one integer ğ‘› (1â‰¤ğ‘›â‰¤2000) â€” the length of ğ‘. The second line of the test case contains ğ‘› integers ğ‘1,ğ‘2,â€¦,ğ‘ğ‘› (1â‰¤ğ‘ğ‘–â‰¤26), where ğ‘ğ‘– is the ğ‘–-th element of ğ‘. Note that the maximum value of ğ‘ğ‘– can be up to 26.

It is guaranteed that the sum of ğ‘› over all test cases does not exceed 2000 (âˆ‘ğ‘›â‰¤2000).

Output
For each test case, print the answer â€” the maximum possible length of some subsequence of ğ‘ that is a three blocks palindrome.

Example
inputCopy
6
8
1 1 2 2 3 2 1 1
3
1 3 3
4
1 10 10 1
1
26
2
2 1
3
1 1 1
outputCopy
7
2
4
1
1
3

entry.title: codefoces Round 633
entry.content:
codefoces Round #633

A
